column1: How childhood cancers are different from adult cancers
Childhood cancers are not the same as adult cancers.
One big difference is that the chance of recovery is high in children.
When cancer occurs in children, it often affects: - Blood cells - Lymph system - Brain - Liver - Bones The most common cancer in children affects blood cells.
While these cancers can happen in adults, they are less common.
Other types of cancer, such as prostate, breast, colon, and lung are more likely in adults than children.
In some children, gene changes that occur during early growth in the womb increase the risk of leukemia.
However, not all children with the mutation get cancer.
Children born with Down syndrome are also more likely to get leukemia.
Scientists have looked at other risk factors including chemicals, toxins, and factors from the mother and father.
Cancer is usually found at a later stage in children compared to adults.
Treatment for childhood cancer is similar to treatment for adult cancer.

It may include: - Chemotherapy - Radiation therapy - Medicines - Immune therapy - Stem cell transplants - Surgery For children, the amount of therapy, type of medicine, or need for surgery may differ from adults.
Some treatments or medicines given to adults are not safe for children.
Your health care team will help you to understand what is right for your child depending on his or her age.
The medicines used to help reduce these symptoms may be different for children compared to adults.
Cancer treatments may also delay growth in children, or cause another cancer to form later on.
Your child will be watched closely by your health care team for many years to look for any late side effects.
